body: // Paradigm: Multi-paradigm: procedural, object-oriented, functional, generic, imperative
// To compile and run this program, use: `g++ filename.cpp -o output && ./output`
C++ Entry Point.description: Creates the entry point of a C++ application.

body: //   - Contains external libraries (if not using a package manager).
// - This is a basic structure; adjust based on project complexity and preferences.
C++ Project Structure (High-Level).description: Explains a high-level project structure for C++.

body: //     - Contains source code for rendering features.
//     - Contains source code for physics features.
//     - Contains source code for networking features.
// - This approach promotes modularity and is suitable for larger projects.
C++ Project Structure (Feature/Module).description: Explains a feature/module-based source directory organization for C++.

body: // Recommended C++ Source Directory Organization (File Type):
// - This approach is simpler but may be less scalable for larger projects.
C++ Project Structure (File Type).description: Explains a file type-based source directory organization for C++.

C++ Mathematical Operators.description: Lists the mathematical operators in C++.

body: C++ is a statically typed language.
- std::string: String class from the Standard Library
- int[10]: Array of integers with size 10
- std::vector<int>: Vector of integers from the Standard Library
- std::map<K, V>: Map (associative array) from the Standard Library
- struct MyStruct: Custom data structure with named fields
- void: Type representing the absence of a value
- auto: Type inferred by the compiler
- nullptr: Type of the null pointer
- decltype: Type specifier for the type of an expression

C++ Date Type.description: C++ doesn't have a built-in Date type. Use std::chrono for date and time operations.

C++ Date Now.description: Gets the current date and time in C++ using std::chrono.

C++ Interpolate String.description: Creates an interpolated string in C++.

body: //   - Type is automatically inferred by the compiler.
//   - Use when auto deduction is not desired or not possible.
//   - Use for values that should remain constant.
// - C++ does not have a direct equivalent to 'var' or 'let'.
// - Use 'const' for values that should not change.

C++ Create Typed Variable.description: Creates a typed variable in C++.

C++ Create Nullable Variable.description: Creates a nullable variable in C++ using std::optional.

C++ Create Integer Variable.description: Creates an integer variable in C++.

C++ Create Double Variable.description: Creates a double variable in C++.

C++ Create Float Variable.description: Creates a float variable in C++.

C++ Create Boolean Variable.description: Creates a boolean variable in C++.

C++ Create String Variable.description: Creates a string variable in C++.

C++ Create Multi-Line String Variable.description: Creates a multi-line string variable in C++.

C++ Create List Variable.description: Creates a list variable in C++.

C++ Create Map Variable.description: Creates a map variable in C++.

C++ Create Date Variable.description: Creates a date variable in C++ using std::chrono.

C++ Create Constant.description: Creates a constant variable in C++.

C++ Static Variable.description: Creates a static variable in a C++ class.

C++ Print.description: Prints a message to the console in C++.

C++ Print Multi.description: Prints a multi-line message to the console in C++.

C++ For Loop.description: Creates a for loop that iterates through a set of numbers with the index in C++.

C++ For...In Loop.description: Iterates over an iterable object in C++.

C++ While Loop.description: Creates a while loop in C++.

C++ Do...While Loop.description: Creates a do...while loop in C++.

C++ Switch Statement.description: Creates a switch statement in C++.

body: // In C++, you can use default arguments in function definitions.
C++ Function Args.description: Creates a function with arguments in C++, including an argument with a default value in the definition.

body: // C++ does not support named arguments in the same way as some other languages.
C++ Function Named Args.description: C++ does not support named arguments in the same way as some other languages.

C++ Lambda Function.description: Creates a lambda function in C++.

body: // Function with arguments: returnType functionName(arg1Type arg1, arg2Type arg2, ...) { ... }
// C++ does not support named arguments in the same way as some other languages.
C++ Function Syntax.description: Outlines the syntax for functions in C++.

C++ Comment.description: Creates a single-line comment in C++.

C++ Multi-Line Comment.description: Creates a multi-line comment in C++.

C++ Try Catch.description: Creates a try...catch block in C++.

C++ If Statement.description: Creates an if statement in C++.

C++ If Else Statement.description: Creates an if...else statement in C++.

C++ Ternary Operator.description: Creates a ternary operator in C++.
